speaker: Doctor
text: Good morning, I'm Dr. Agent. Can you tell me a little bit about yourself and why you're here today?

speaker: Patient
text: I'm 16, a high school student. I'm here because I haven't gotten my period yet and I'm a bit concerned about it.

speaker: Doctor
text: So, you're 16 years old, and you're here today because your parents are concerned about your delayed menarche, is that right?

speaker: Patient
text: Yeah, my mom said it's normal for girls to get their period around this age, but I've never had any bleeding or anything like that.

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to take a closer look at your physical appearance. Can you tell me about your family history, have you noticed any unusual physical features in yourself or your relatives that might be worth mentioning?

speaker: Patient
text: My mom had some hair growth on her chin when she was pregnant with me, and I've always thought my clitoris was a bit... larger than usual, but I don't know if that's normal.

speaker: Doctor
text: I see you have a few interesting features, such as a short stature and a slightly webbed neck. Can you tell me if you've ever had any problems with your bones, like frequent fractures or a lot of back pain?

speaker: Patient
text: Actually, I've had a few pretty bad injuries over the years, and I've broken a few bones when I fell or got hit by something. Like, I broke my wrist when I fell off my bike, and my arm when I got hit by a ball.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of your physical features and family history. Have you ever experienced any issues with your skin, such as cold intolerance or a lot of bruising?

speaker: Patient
text: Yeah, I've had really bad acne for a while now. It's been pretty severe, and I've been taking oral medication for it.

speaker: Doctor
text: You mentioned a webbed neck, can you show me exactly what you mean by that?

speaker: Patient
text: I'm not sure if it's a webbed neck, I just feel like my neck is a bit... asymmetrical, I guess.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken a look at your webbed neck, and it does appear to be a bit more pronounced than usual. Have you ever had any issues with your thyroid gland, such as a goiter or difficulty swallowing?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I don't think so. But I have noticed that my skin is really sensitive to the cold, and I get really cold even in mild temperatures.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've noticed that you have a slight indentation in your palate, it looks like a small cleft. Can you tell me if you've ever had any dental issues or difficulties with eating due to a cleft palate?

speaker: Patient
text: I've had some issues with my teeth, I've had to have a few of them removed because they were really crooked and overlapping. And eating can be a bit of a challenge sometimes, especially if I'm eating something crunchy or hard.

speaker: Doctor
text: You've had a cleft palate, that's interesting. Have you had any surgery to correct it, or has it been managed conservatively?

speaker: Patient
text: I've had a few surgeries to correct it, but I still have some issues with eating certain foods. And, to be honest, I've had some problems with my skin breaking out after those surgeries.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've made a note of the cleft palate, and I'd like to know more about your overall health. Have you ever experienced any issues with your growth and development, such as delayed puberty or short stature in comparison to your peers?

speaker: Patient
text: Yeah, I'm actually a lot shorter than most of the other girls in my class, and I've always been a bit concerned about it. And, to be honest, I've also had some issues with my skin getting really oily and breaking out in a lot of places.

speaker: Doctor
text: You've been experiencing some issues with your growth and development, and you've also had a cleft palate that's been managed conservatively. I'd like to ask, have you ever had any problems with your menstrual cycle, other than the delayed menarche, such as irregular periods or heavy bleeding?

speaker: Patient
text: To be honest, I've never had any periods at all, so I don't really know what irregular or heavy bleeding would be like for me.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of your issues with your menstrual cycle. Have you ever had any unusual bleeding or discharge, such as spotting between periods or after physical activity?

speaker: Patient
text: Honestly, I've never really had any bleeding or discharge like that. But I do get a lot of pain in my lower abdomen, especially after I exercise or do something physically demanding. It's not always there, but when it is, it can be pretty intense.

speaker: Doctor
text: I see that you've had some irregular bleeding and spotting, can you tell me if this is a new development or has it been a persistent issue throughout your life?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I don't think it's been a persistent issue. I've always been a bit uncomfortable down there, but I never really associated it with bleeding or spotting until now.

speaker: Doctor
text: So, the irregular bleeding and spotting have been a persistent issue throughout your life. That's helpful to know. Have you ever experienced any intellectual or cognitive difficulties, such as learning disabilities or difficulties in school?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I've never had any issues with learning or school. I'm actually a pretty good student and I've always done well in my classes.

speaker: Doctor
text: You mentioned that you've had some irregular bleeding and spotting, and that it's been a persistent issue throughout your life. Can you tell me if you've ever experienced any pain or cramping associated with these bleeding episodes?

speaker: Patient
text: Yeah, I've had some pretty bad cramps with the pain, especially after I exercise or do something physically demanding. It's usually in my lower abdomen, and it can be really intense.

speaker: Doctor
text: So, the irregular bleeding and spotting have been a persistent issue, and you've also experienced some pain or cramping associated with these bleeding episodes. Can you tell me if you've ever had any issues with your immune system, such as frequent infections or prolonged illnesses?

speaker: Patient
text: Actually, I've had a pretty good immune system, I don't get sick often and I recover quickly when I do get sick. But I have been on a lot of medications, including oral isotretinoin for my acne and an oral contraceptive, so I'm not sure if that affects my immune system at all.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of your issues with your immune system, and I'd like to ask, have you ever been diagnosed with any autoimmune disorders or conditions that affect the immune system?

speaker: Patient
text: To be honest, my mom has been worried that I might have something like that because I've had so many problems with my bones and skin. But I've never actually been diagnosed with anything like that.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of your family history, physical features, and health issues. Can you tell me if anyone in your family has been diagnosed with Turner syndrome or any other chromosomal abnormalities?

speaker: Patient
text: My mom's side of the family has a history of some pretty rare medical conditions, but I'm not really sure what they are. My grandma had some kind of hormone imbalance that caused her to have some unusual physical features, but I don't know the specifics.

speaker: Doctor
text: I see that you have a family history of Turner syndrome, which is a significant finding. Can you tell me if you've ever experienced any issues with your hearing or vision?

speaker: Patient
text: Actually, I've never had any problems with my hearing or vision, and I've never needed glasses or hearing aids. But I have had some issues with my balance and coordination, I've had a few falls and gotten hurt pretty easily.

speaker: Doctor
text:
With that final question answered, I have enough information to make a diagnosis. However, I must admit that the fact that another doctor with similar symptoms to yours was diagnosed with cancer has left me with some concerns.

DIAGNOSIS READY: Turner Syndrome
